text:
When are you not allowed
to sound your vehicle's
horn?

options.A: Between 11.30 pm and 6.00 am on any road
options.B: Between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am in a built-up area
options.C: At any time in a built-up area
options.D: Between 10.00 pm and 6.00 am in a built-up area

explanation: Between 11.30 pm and 7.00 am in a built-up area. You must not sound your horn in a built-up area between these hours except when another vehicle poses a danger.

text:

explanation: Before starting a journey. Tyre checks should be part of your regular routine before driving, not during the journey.

text:
When should tyre

explanation: Stop in a safe place when you can. Never stop on the motorway to make adjustments - find a safe place like a service area.

text:

use more fuel?

options.C: When its tyres are of different makes

explanation: Before you start your journey. All vehicle checks, including lights, should be done before you drive.

text:

explanation: It could seriously injure you in a collision. Loose objects become dangerous projectiles in a crash, causing serious injury.

text:

What level should you fill it

text:
How can you plan your
route before starting a long
journey?

options.C: Use a route planner on the internet

explanation: Move back and use your mirrors. You must have a clear view behind. If the load blocks your view, use mirrors or ask someone to guide you.

text:
Why is it a good idea to
plan your journey to avoid
busy times?

options.A: You'll have a more stressful journey
options.B: Your journey time will be longer
options.C: It will cause more traffic congestion

explanation: Check your mirrors. Always check mirrors before signaling to be aware of other traffic around you.

text:
How will your journey be
affected by travelling
outside the busy times of
day?

options.B: Your journey will use more fuel
options.C: Your journey will be more hazardous
options.D: Your journey will have fewer delays

explanation: Every 600 miles. Oil levels should be checked regularly - every 600 miles or weekly, whichever comes first.

text:

an alternative route?

options.A: You may get held up by a tractor
options.B: You may find you have to pay a congestion charge
options.C: Your maps may have different scales
options.D: Your original route may be blocked

explanation: Fuel consumption will increase. Incorrect tyre pressure increases rolling resistance, leading to higher fuel consumption.

text:
You have to arrive on
time for an appointment.
How should you plan for the
journey?

options.A: Avoid roads with the national speed limit
options.B: Allow plenty of time for the trip
options.C: Plan to travel at busy times

explanation: You'll have a reduced view behind. Tinted glass reduces visibility, especially in poor light conditions, making it harder to see behind.

text:
What can you expect if
you drive using rapid
acceleration and heavy
braking?
explanation: Reduce your speed and turn on dipped headlights. In fog, slow down and use dipped headlights to help you see and be seen.

text:

crash if the level is allowed
to get too low?
explanation: Before a long journey. Check all fluid levels, including coolant, as part of your pre-journey vehicle checks.

text:

your anti-lock brakes (ABS)
warning light stays on?

options.D: Check that the parking brake is released

explanation: Stop and rectify the problem immediately. Loose wheels are extremely dangerous and must be fixed before continuing.

text:

driving?

options.B: A fault in the braking system

explanation: Put the reflective side towards you. The reflective side should face inward to reflect your body heat back to you.

options.C: To maintain control of the pedals
options.D: To enable you to adjust your seat

explanation: Check tyre pressures. Correct tyre pressure reduces rolling resistance, improving fuel economy.

explanation: Before driving. All pre-drive checks should be done before you start your journey.

explanation: Stop as soon as it's safe and check your tyres. A bumpy ride suggests tyre or suspension problems requiring immediate attention.

options.A: Park in a poorly lit area
options.B: Leave it in a well-lit area
options.C: Park in a quiet side road

explanation: Dispose of it at a local authority site. Engine oil must be disposed of properly at authorized facilities.

text:

keep your car secure?

options.C: Registering with a Vehicle Watch scheme
options.D: Being a member of a vehicle breakdown organisation

explanation: Driving smoothly. Smooth driving with gentle acceleration and braking uses less fuel and reduces emissions.

text:

you drive smoothly?

options.A: Reduction in journey times by about 15%
options.B: Increase in journey times by about 15%
options.C: Reduction in fuel consumption by about 15%
options.D: Increase in fuel consumption by about 15%

text:

options.D: Using lower gears as often as possible

explanation: It must be securely fastened. All cargo must be secured to prevent it shifting or falling during driving.

text:
How can driving in a
fuel-efficient manner help
protect the environment?

options.B: Through the legal enforcement of speed regulations
options.C: By increasing the number of cars on the road

explanation: By reducing exhaust emissions. Fuel-efficient driving means less fuel burned and fewer harmful emissions released into the atmosphere.

text:
What's the legal
minimum tread depth for
tyres on your trailer or
caravan?
explanation: 1.6 mm. The legal minimum tread depth for trailer and caravan tyres is the same as for cars - 1.6mm across the central three-quarters of the tread.

text:
When may a passenger
travel in a car without
wearing a seat belt?

options.A: When they're under 1.5 metres (5 feet) in height
options.B: When they're exempt for medical reasons
options.C: When they're sitting in the rear seat

explanation: When they're exempt for medical reasons. Passengers can only travel without seat belts if they have a valid medical exemption certificate.

text:
You're driving a friend's children home from school. They're both under 14 years old. Who's responsible for making sure they wear a 
seat belt or approved child restraint where required?
explanation: You, the driver. The driver is responsible for ensuring all passengers under 14 wear seat belts or appropriate child restraints.

text:
What's likely to happen if
you put too much oil in your
engine?

options.C: The air intake will become blocked

explanation: The oil seals will leak. Excess oil creates pressure in the engine, which can cause seals to fail and leak.

text:
You have to make an 
unexpected journey. You're carrying a five-year-old child on the back seat of your car. They're under 1.35 metres (4 feet 5 inches) tall. How 
should you seat them if a 
correct child restraint isn't available?

options.A: Sharing a belt with an adult

explanation: Using an adult seat belt. In unexpected journeys where a child restraint isn't available, use an adult seat belt rather than no restraint.

text: You're carrying an 11-year-old child on the front seat of your car. They're under 1.35 metres (4 feet 5 inches) tall. What seat belt security must be in place?

options.A: They must be able to see clearly out of the front window
options.B: They must use an adult seat belt
options.C: They must be able to fasten their own seat belt
options.D: They must use a suitable child restraint

explanation: They must use a suitable child restraint. Children under 1.35m tall must use an appropriate child restraint in the front seat.

text:
You're stopped at the
side of the road. What must
you do if you'll be waiting
there for some time?
explanation: Switch off the engine. When stationary for any length of time, turn off the engine to reduce emissions and save fuel.

text:
You want to put a rear-facing baby seat on the front passenger seat. What must you do if the passenger seat is protected by a frontal 
airbag?

options.A: Put the child in an adult seat belt
options.C: Turn the seat to face sideways
options.D: Ask a passenger to hold the baby

explanation: Deactivate the airbag. Rear-facing child seats must never be used with an active airbag as it can cause serious injury. The airbag must be deactivated.

text:
You're leaving your
vehicle parked on a road
and unattended. When may
you leave the engine
running?

options.A: If you'll be parking for less than five minutes
options.B: Never if you're away from the vehicle
options.C: When parked in a 20 mph zone
options.D: If the battery keeps going flat

explanation: Never if you're away from the vehicle. You must never leave a vehicle with the engine running unattended - it's illegal and a security risk.
